item.title: In Moldova, a Pro-Russian Oligarch With a Criminal Past Tries to Derail Path to Europe
item.description: Ilan Shor fled to Russia after being convicted in a $1 billion bank heist. Now he aims to topple Moldova’s government.

item.title: Pentagon Chief Arrives in Kyiv Without Any Sign of Budging on Ukraine's Biggest Weapons Requests
item.description: U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has helped bolster Ukraine’s fight against Russia but has argued for limiting military aid.

item.title: Russia Turns Mariupol's Steel Mills From Battle Zone to Spoils of War
item.description: Moscow’s patronage enriches a Kremlin-friendly warlord from Chechnya by letting him plunder a big metals plant.

item.title: Israel Killed Sinwar by Forcing Him From the Tunnels
item.description: The Israeli military attacked strategic underground complexes in Gaza, pushing Yahya Sinwar to leave the safety of Hamas’s labyrinth.

item.title: Israel Expands Lebanon Campaign With Strikes on Banks It Links to Hezbollah
item.description: Its air force hit branches of Al-Qard Al-Hassan, a U.S.-sanctioned bank that the Israeli military says is central to Hezbollah’s economic functioning.

item.title: U.S. Investigates Intelligence Leak About Israel's Plans for Attacking Iran
item.description: Two highly classified reports about Israel’s preparations for striking Iran were posted online by a pro-Iran site.

item.title: In Death, Hamas Leader May Have Won Wider Support Than When He Was Alive
item.description: Across the Arab world, U.S.-aligned governments are finding themselves in difficult positions as clerics and citizens praise Yahya Sinwar.

item.title: Scatterand Survive: Inside a U.S.Military Shift to Deny China 'Big, Juicy' Targets
item.description: America is upgrading far-off runways and reviving World War II airfields to counter the threat of China’s enormous missile arsenal.

item.title: Israel Says Drone From Lebanon Flew Toward Netanyahu's Home
item.description: The prime minister and his family weren’t present at the private residence in Caesarea, according to his office.

item.title: Are the Amazon's Trees Worth More Alive than Dead? A New Industry Thinks So
item.description: Brazil is encouraging bioplastics, ecotourism and fishing businesses in the rainforest to replace illegal logging and mining.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Has a Big Political Problem: Justin Trudeau
item.description: The Canadian leader gave his country’s politics a makeover in the past decade. Now, many Canadians want a new look.

item.title: Sinwar's Bloody Gambit Changed the Middle East---but Not as He Imagined
item.description: Israel was wounded by last year’s Oct. 7 attack, but didn’t fold. Now Palestinian statehood is more remote than ever.

item.title: Behind the Mysterious Downfall of China's Missing Foreign Minister
item.description: A three-part podcast series digs into why Qin Gang vanished from view in June 2023.

item.title: U.S. Presses to End Gaza War After Death of Hamas Leader
item.description: Israel and Hamas signal they aren’t ready for a cease-fire, as the White House seeks a broad diplomatic deal.

item.title: A Battered HamasCharts PathWithout Its Chief Strategist
item.description: After Yahya Sinwar’s death, the Palestinian militant group must craft a new blueprint in its war with Israel.

item.title: Patricia Taylor, Whose Efforts to Hide Americans in Iran Were Depicted in 'Argo,' Dies at 95
item.description: A scientist, dancer, musician and host, she worked at the center of both the Iranian hostage crisis and the AIDS crisis while supporting her diplomat husband.

item.title: Cuba Suffers Mass Blackout as Energy Crisis Deepens
item.description: The Communist government ordered the closure of nonvital activities hours to avoid power grid collapse.

item.title: Archie Karas, a Gambling Legend Who Made---and Lost---a Fortune, Dies at 73
item.description: Over a three-year span in the 1990s, Karas won as much as $40 million—only to lose it all in a fraction of the time it took to win it.

item.title: After a Yearlong Hunt, Sinwar's Killing Came Down to Chance
item.description: Cornered in a bombed-out building, the architect of the Oct. 7 attacks died alone, but his defiance could make him a martyr for Hamas and its supporters.

item.title: Hamas Chief Yahya Sinwar Killed in Gaza, Israel Says
item.description: Sinwar, a U.S.-designated terrorist, in October 2023 triggered a war with Israel in Gaza that has since expanded to a multifront conflict in the Middle East.
